title: Designing the data science classroom
text:
Learning objectives
Curriculum, workflow, and infrastructure design for teaching data science with R and RStudio.

title: Designing the data science classroom
text:
Is this course for me?
If your answer to any of the following questions is ‚Äúyes‚Äù, then this is the right workshop for you.

Do you want to learn / discuss curriculum, pedagogy, and computing infrastructure design for teaching data science with R and RStudio?
Are you interested in setting up your class in RStudio Cloud?
Do you want to integrate version control with git into your teaching and learn about tools and best practices for running your course on GitHub?

title: Designing the data science classroom
text:
Prework
In this workshop you will wear two hats: the educator and the learner. At times we will be demoing workflows for instructors (whom I assume are familiar with R, RStudio, and the tidyverse and have taught with or are interested in teaching with RStudio Cloud, Git, and GitHub) and at other times you will be working through the student view (on RStudio Cloud, assuming you‚Äôre not using your local setup).
For the latter, you can mostly assume that you‚Äôre a student in an intro data science course and this is the first day of class (i.e.¬†there‚Äôs no expectation of prep). However we‚Äôd also like to give you a taste of how the remainder of the semester goes, which often entails students watching background videos to prepare. To prepare for the first module, please watch the following video before the workshop.
üé• Let them eat cake (first)!
üñ•Ô∏è Slides
For the former, you‚Äôll might need to prepare a bit more. If you already are a Git and GitHub user, have a personal token saved, and can push to and pull from GitHub without having to type your password in each time, you‚Äôre good to go. If not, please complete the following steps before the workshop1. If you need help with any of the steps, please ask on GitHub Discussions.

Register a free GitHub account
Install or update R and RStudio
Install Git
Introduce yourself to Git
Personal access token for HTTPS
Connect to GitHub
Connect RStudio to Git and GitHub
Detect Git from RStudio

If you choose to use your local R and RStudio install for the workshop, you should also install the following packages:

From CRAN:

install.packages("devtools")
install.packages("DT")

install.packages("rvest")
install.packages("shiny")
install.packages("sortable")
install.packages("tidyverse")
install.packages("tidymodels")
install.packages("unvotes")

From GitHub:

devtools::install_github("gadenbuie/countdown")
devtools::install_github("rstudio/parsons")

Code checking

No built in code checking feature, but hooks for using other packages for code checking
gradethis is furthest along: https://github.com/rstudio-education/gradethis

title: Interactivity and immediate feedback with learnr
text:
Recording events

Recording events like exercise and question submissions, requests for hints/solutions, etc.
This is possible with learnr, though not very simple
With other R tools that allow for writing out to spreadsheets (e.g.¬†Google Sheets) and building dashboards (e.g.¬†shinydashboard) it‚Äôs possible to build a dashboard for your class where you can track their progress and learn from what they‚Äôre struggling with

title: Interactivity and immediate feedback with learnr
text:
A simpler hack: ‚ÄúMinute paper‚Äù
Add a link at the end of your tutorial to a Google (or other) form

Write about one or two questions you didn‚Äôt get right initially but were able to solve after a few tries. What was difficult about them? What did you ultimately learn?

OR

If you got every single question correct on the first try, write one question you would still like clarified on the topics covered in this quiz.
